Title: Second Contact
Antagonists: Rage virus outbreak aboard the Cerritos
Summary: The California‑class starship USS Cerritos arrives at the capital planet of the Galar system to perform a routine second contact mission with the Galardonians, while newly assigned Orion ensign D'Vana Tendi experiences her first day aboard ship. Ambitious rule‑following Brad Boimler is secretly ordered by Captain Carol Freeman to report any infractions committed by the insubordinate Beckett Mariner—who, unbeknownst to him, is the captain's daughter. On the surface, Boimler discovers Mariner quietly smuggling surplus Federation equipment to struggling local farmers, even as a ravenous barn spider attacks and literally strips him to his underwear. Meanwhile, first officer Jack Ransom brings a mysterious bug bite back to the Cerritos, triggering a fast‑moving "rage virus" that turns much of the crew into black‑vomit‑spewing berserkers. As Tendi assists cranky Caitian doctor T'Ana in Sickbay and engineer Sam Rutherford tries to continue a date with Trill helm officer Barnes while fighting off infected crewmates, Boimler is covered in the spider's mucus. T'Ana realizes the slime contains antibodies, synthesizes a cure, and saves the ship, earning the captain's praise. Boimler ultimately chooses not to betray Mariner to Freeman, cementing their uneasy friendship while leaving the captain still scheming for a way to transfer her troublemaking daughter off the Cerritos.

StorySections.Text: On Douglas Station above Earth, Ensign Brad Boimler records a self‑important log entry about the USS Cerritos' upcoming second contact mission with the Galardonians, only to be interrupted when Beckett Mariner drunkenly bursts into the warp core room wielding a contraband bat'leth. She chases simulated "Borg" through the corridors, nicking Boimler in the leg and exposing just how far she is from the idealized Starfleet officer he aspires to be.

The Cerritos departs for the Galar system as newly assigned medical ensign D'Vana Tendi arrives on board, wide‑eyed and thrilled to be in Starfleet. Boimler and Mariner give her a whirlwind tour of the ship. In the midst of their bickering, Captain Carol Freeman privately orders Boimler to spy on Mariner and report every infraction, promising it will be "good for his career." Down on the planet, Mariner ignores protocol to chat with common farmers, while Boimler tries to stick to the mission profile and keep her under control.

While Boimler frets over his secret assignment, Rutherford nervously prepares for a date with Trill ensign Barnes, relying on the logic‑driven Vulcan cybernetic implant recently installed in his head. The two lower‑deckers work through their jitters by running maintenance in the Jefferies tubes, where Rutherford realizes that solving engineering problems excites him far more than romance. On the surface, Boimler catches Mariner handing out Federation gear to impoverished farmers. Before he can decide whether to report her, a massive barn spider attacks, seizing Boimler and coating him in sticky mucus.

Mariner eventually learns from a local that the spider is actually an herbivore "milking" Boimler for moisture, not eating him, and calmly waits for it to tire itself out before stunning the creature and rescuing him—though not before his uniform is dissolved, forcing him to don rough overalls. Meanwhile, first officer Jack Ransom, bitten by an insect during a ceremonial greeting, unknowingly carries an alien pathogen back to the ship. The "rage virus" infects crew members across decks, turning them pallid‑skinned, yellow‑eyed, and feral. Tendi rushes into Sickbay amid chaos as T'Ana struggles to restrain patients and save a dying Chief Engineer Billups.

As the outbreak spreads, security chief Shaxs recommends blowing the warp core, but Freeman refuses to abandon her ship. Rutherford and Barnes fight their way through zombie‑like crewmates to reach an exterior access hatch, chatting awkwardly about hobbies even as they spacewalk along the hull under fire. In Sickbay, T'Ana realizes that the black goop coating Boimler is actually the spider's secretions, containing antibodies that neutralize the virus. She uses a sample to synthesize a cure, and the medical staff races through the ship injecting afflicted crew until the crisis is contained.

With the Cerritos saved and the Galardonian second contact formally completed, Captain Freeman commends Dr. T'Ana for her quick thinking but is frustrated that Mariner's latest bout of insubordination went unreported. Boimler, having seen Mariner risk herself to protect civilians and him, chooses not to betray her—sacrificing an easy career boost to do what he believes is right. Mariner thanks him and offers to help him climb the ladder, while Freeman privately fumes, still determined to find a way to remove her own rebellious daughter from her ship.

BehindTheScenes: “Second Contact” is the premiere episode of Star Trek: Lower Decks and introduces the USS Cerritos, its California‑class design, and the core ensemble of lower‑decks ensigns.

The episode contains numerous visual callbacks to earlier Star Trek series, including a dune buggy reminiscent of the Argo from Star Trek: Nemesis and a spacedock model similar to that seen in Star Trek III.

Lower Decks' comedic tone is established here by juxtaposing classic Star Trek crises—plagues, giant creatures, and diplomatic ceremonies—with mundane concerns like first dates and performance reviews.

Title: Envoys
Summary: The Cerritos ferries legendary Klingon general K'orin to a Federation embassy on Tulgana IV, and Brad Boimler is thrilled to be assigned as the general's escort—until Beckett Mariner muscles her way onto the mission and immediately undercuts his carefully prepared plans. On the chaotic multi‑species world below, K'orin escapes in a drunken stupor, forcing the two ensigns to hunt for him through dangerous districts that Mariner knows far better than Boimler, exacerbating his fear that he is not cut out for real‑world Starfleet service. Aboard the Cerritos, Sam Rutherford considers abandoning engineering so he can match new friend D'Vana Tendi's excitement about watching a pulsar, cycling through security, command, and medical assignments before realizing that his true passion remains the warp core. After Mariner secretly hires an alien shapeshifter to stage a fake attack that Boimler can "defeat," restoring his shaken confidence, the two ensigns return K'orin to the embassy just in time—only for Q to briefly intrude with an over‑the‑top trial that the exhausted lower‑deckers flatly refuse to indulge.

StorySections.Text: As the Cerritos travels at warp, the crew encounters an energy being that demands worship and threatens to punish their "lesser" minds. Mariner captures it in a canister and trades its freedom for a fancy new tricorder, sending the diminished entity drifting off in a huff while Boimler sputters about violations of first contact protocol.

Captain Freeman assigns Boimler to escort famed Klingon general K'orin to a Federation embassy on Tulgana IV, a duty the by‑the‑book ensign views as a career‑making opportunity. Mariner, who recognizes K'orin from past misadventures, invites herself along, irritating Boimler with her casual familiarity and improvised drinking games. When K'orin steals a shuttle and heads to the planet's surface for a night of revelry, the junior officers are forced to follow in a replacement shuttle to recover him.

On Tulgana IV, Boimler attempts to rely on regulations and Starfleet diplomacy in the face of hostile locals and labyrinthine alien neighborhoods, but he is quickly overwhelmed. Mariner, who has clearly spent time in similar border‑world dives, drags him through Andorian bars, Orion districts, and rough back alleys as they search for the missing general. Each time Boimler tries to take charge, her street smarts and connections solve the situation instead, leaving him humiliated and questioning his abilities.

Aboard the Cerritos, Rutherford hears Tendi's excitement about watching a nearby pulsar and decides to transfer out of engineering so they can spend more time together. He samples the security division under Shaxs, where he discovers he enjoys tactical drills but balks at the constant desire to blow things up. In command training, he briefly relishes being at the conn before a simulated disaster overwhelms him. A stint in Sickbay under Dr. T'Ana proves equally ill‑suited, and Rutherford slowly realizes how much he misses working in the Jeffries tubes.

On Tulgana IV, Boimler finally breaks down, declaring that he plans to quit Starfleet because Mariner is better at everything that seems to matter on dangerous away missions. Unbeknownst to him, she has paid a Vendorian shapeshifter to pose as an attacker so Boimler can talk it down and "save" her, giving him a contrived confidence boost. The ruse works: Boimler believes he stood up to a lethal threat, and his faith in his place in Starfleet is restored. The pair ultimately track down a drunken K'orin in a dive bar and drag him—still passed out—back to the embassy.

Back aboard the Cerritos, Rutherford happily returns to engineering, reassured that Tendi enjoys spending time with him no matter what division he serves in. On the shuttle bay, Q suddenly appears, attempting to subject the Cerritos crew to one of his trademark surreal trials, but Mariner and Boimler, exhausted from their misadventures, brush him off and tell him to go bother Jean‑Luc Picard instead, leaving the omnipotent trickster sputtering in disbelief.

Title: Temporal Edict
Summary: When Starfleet Command chews out Captain Freeman for the Cerritos' habit of arriving late to diplomatic engagements, she responds by eliminating informal "buffer time" from the crew's schedules, instituting a rigid temporal edict that tracks and punishes every lost second. As overworked officers stumble and make mistakes, an away team led by Jack Ransom and including Beckett Mariner visits the crystal‑obsessed world of Gelrak 5, only to insult their hosts by presenting the wrong ceremonial totem. The enraged Gelrakians capture the away team and threaten execution just as the undermanned Cerritos loses systems to cascading errors. With the ship and crew pushed to the breaking point, Mariner and Ransom are forced to put aside their mutual contempt, leading a brutal gladiatorial brawl in the Gelrakian arena while Boimler inadvertently proves that flexible scheduling actually maximizes efficiency. Freeman ultimately rescinds her edict, restoring buffer time and saving both the mission and her crew.

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is harassed by an irate Klingon captain who demands that Captain Freeman stop blasting bass music at his ship. In truth, the noise is coming from the Cerritos' own crew partying in the lower decks, a scene that underscores how much informal downtime the ship's officers have built into their schedules.

After Starfleet reprimands her for late arrivals and poor time management metrics, Captain Freeman institutes a "temporal edict" banning unscheduled downtime and assigning precise completion windows for every task, to the second. Boimler eagerly embraces the new order, viewing it as validation of his meticulous habits, while Mariner and most of the crew chafe under the impossible workloads. Even simple jobs, like repainting hull markings, turn into frantic sprints as officers rush to avoid punishment.

Ransom leads an away team—including Mariner—to the crystal‑worshipping planet Gelrak 5 to present an honor crystal as part of a new agreement. Thanks to the temporal edict's disruptions, the wrong ceremonial totem is loaded onto the shuttle, and Ransom unknowingly offers a wooden fertility idol instead of the expected crystal. The insult enrages the Gelrakian magistrate, who orders the offworlders imprisoned and demands blood in recompense.

Back on the Cerritos, Freeman's time‑tracking regime causes cascading failures as exhausted crew members start cutting corners. Tendi and Rutherford scramble to complete tasks in ludicrously short windows, accidentally deleting data and misconfiguring systems, while Shaxs fumes that security drills are being shortchanged. On Gelrak 5, the magistrate sentences the away team to trial by combat, forcing Mariner and Ransom into an arena surrounded by crystal‑armed warriors.

In the arena, Mariner and Ransom drop their sniping and fight back‑to‑back in a surprisingly brutal, bare‑knuckle battle against multiple Gelrakians. Ransom ultimately gains the upper hand and is granted the right to execute Mariner for insubordination, but instead chooses to spare her, impressing the locals and satisfying their code of honor. Meanwhile, Boimler demonstrates that allowing officers to estimate their own task times actually improves efficiency, convincing Freeman that her edict is self‑defeating.

Freeman rescinds the temporal edict, restoring informal buffer time and ordering the computer to stop tracking every second of crew activity. A delighted Mariner celebrates with drinks in the bar, while Boimler, crushed that his beloved scheduling regime has been scrapped, awkwardly tries to pretend he always supported the return to looser, more human‑scale Starfleet working conditions.

Title: Moist Vessel
Summary: The Cerritos teams up with the USS Merced, commanded by Tellarite Captain Durango, to tow an ancient generation ship whose cargo of unstable terraforming fluid can reconfigure matter on contact. Seeking to rein in Beckett Mariner's insubordination, Captain Freeman tries to punish her by promoting her to senior officer, forcing Mariner into meetings, dress‑uniform inspections, and tedious ceremonial duties that she sabotages with increasingly immature behavior. Meanwhile, D'Vana Tendi befriends Ensign O'Connor, a smug ascetic striving to achieve literal ascension into a higher plane, and her overeager attempts to help accidentally ruin his big ritual. When Durango recklessly adjusts his ship's tractor beam to "look better" during the joint operation, the generation vessel ruptures, flooding both ships with terraforming goo that begins transforming bulkheads and crew alike into surreal organic structures. As Freeman and Mariner struggle to save trapped officers amid the chaos, a panicked O'Connor finally achieves brief, ecstatic ascension, giving Tendi an awe‑inspiring glimpse of the cosmos before everything snaps back to normal.

StorySections.Text: During a routine briefing, Captain Freeman presents the mission to tow a derelict generation ship filled with experimental terraforming fluid, while Mariner visibly tunes out. After the meeting, Freeman vents to Admiral Freeman about her daughter's behavior and is advised to try promoting Mariner into responsibility rather than simply reprimanding her.

Freeman abruptly promotes Mariner to lieutenant, making her a senior officer. Mariner expects this to be a reward, but quickly discovers that it comes with endless staff meetings, dress‑code enforcement, and the obligation to set an example for junior crew. She is assigned a shared quarters upgrade with a view, which she hates because it separates her from the lower‑decks vibe. Determined to rebel, she starts acting out even more obnoxiously in briefings and ceremonies.

As the Cerritos and Merced begin their joint tow of the generation ship, Freeman tries to showcase inter‑ship professionalism, but Durango becomes increasingly insecure about perceived slights. Elsewhere, Tendi meets Ensign O'Connor, who claims to be on the verge of spiritual ascension and invites her to witness the moment he transcends physical existence. Tendi, excited but clueless about meditation, keeps interrupting his rituals with questions and small talk, much to his growing frustration.

At a formal ceremony with both bridge crews present, Mariner deliberately undermines Freeman by goofing off, chewing gum, and generally acting like the galaxy's worst lieutenant. Embarrassed and fed up, Freeman has her demoted back to ensign in front of the assembled officers. Stung, Mariner storms off just as Durango, still trying to one‑up the Cerritos, alters the tractor beam configuration so the Merced will be in the more photogenic position. The change destabilizes the generation ship, causing it to rupture and spill terraforming fluid into space.

Terraforming fluid engulfs both vessels, transforming decks into churning organic growths and crystalline forests. Freeman and Mariner rush to rescue trapped officers, including a panicked Durango, climbing through corridors that warp into new shapes around them. In a cargo bay, Tendi and O'Connor are tossed about as the room morphs, and in a surge of fear and self‑reflection, O'Connor unexpectedly achieves a brief, radiant ascension, rising into a cosmic lightshow that gives Tendi a mind‑bending glimpse of higher dimensions before he vanishes. The terraforming process then reverses after the crew vent the fluid, returning both ships to normal.

With the crisis resolved, Freeman and Mariner reach a wary truce, acknowledging that their mother‑daughter relationship complicates their chain of command but agreeing to keep trying. Tendi, still reeling from her encounter with genuine ascension, sheepishly admits that she accidentally sabotaged nearly all of O'Connor's earlier attempts, while Rutherford and Boimler joke about how even a mundane towing mission can turn into an existential horror show on the Cerritos.

Title: Cupid's Errant Arrow
Summary: The Cerritos rendezvous with the more advanced USS Vancouver to assist in the controlled demolition of an unstable moon whose orbit threatens to annihilate its parent planet. Brad Boimler is elated to be reunited with his girlfriend, Vancouver science officer Lieutenant Barbara Brinson, and drags Beckett Mariner along to prove that Barb is real and that their relationship is healthy. Mariner, however, becomes convinced that something is deeply wrong—asserting that Barb must secretly be a spy, robot, or parasite to find Boimler that appealing—sparking a hysterical investigation that nearly derails the mission. Meanwhile, Sam Rutherford and D'Vana Tendi are dazzled by the Vancouver's cutting‑edge technology and try to wrangle transfers before realizing that life aboard a high‑profile ship is its own kind of pressure. In the end, Mariner is vindicated when a glowing brain‑sucking parasite is discovered latched to Boimler's head, explaining Barb's inexplicable attraction and forcing the couple's breakup as the parasite is removed.

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is assigned to support the USS Vancouver on a high‑stakes operation to prevent an unstable moon from destroying its planet, a mission that instantly makes the lower‑deckers feel overshadowed by the sleeker, more prestigious starship and its crew.

Boimler frantically prepares to see Lieutenant Barb Brinson, the Vancouver officer he has been dating long‑distance, and begs Mariner not to embarrass him. When Barb arrives and turns out to be confident, competent, and apparently genuinely into Boimler, Mariner's suspicion is immediately piqued. She starts watching Barb for any sign that she is an infiltrator or alien impostor, irritating both Boimler and their Vancouver hosts.

On the Vancouver, Tendi and Rutherford are given tours of the ship's advanced systems and new‑model equipment, including portable transport enhancers and sleek duty gear. They are so dazzled that they compete with one another for a coveted transfer voucher that would allow them to join the Vancouver's permanent crew. Back on the planet, Mariner interrogates Boimler about Barb's history and concocts increasingly wild theories about what kind of monster she must be.

As Freeman, Ransom, and Captain Amina Ramdar juggle political demands from various factions who all claim the unstable moon for different reasons, Mariner sneaks into Barb's quarters to look for evidence. She finds nothing incriminating, but when she confronts Barb, the two women brawl across corridors and into a cargo bay, accusing each other of being the real threat. Their fight is interrupted when a small, luminescent parasite is spotted clinging to Boimler's head.

Barb reveals that the parasite exudes pheromones and neurological signals that made Boimler seem irresistibly attractive and hyper‑competent, explaining why she fell for him so hard and why his behavior recently seemed off. Once the creature is removed and contained, the artificial "spark" between them fades, leading to an awkward but amicable breakup. On the Vancouver, Tendi and Rutherford realize that the ship's glamorous missions come with crushing stress that has burned out their guide, so they tear up their transfer voucher and happily return to the Cerritos, where expectations are lower but friendships are stronger.

Back aboard the Cerritos, Mariner teases Boimler about having literally been love‑bugged, while grudgingly admitting that Barb was otherwise a solid officer. Boimler sulks over losing both his girlfriend and the flattering parasite, as Tendi and Rutherford revel in the comfort of their familiar, slightly shabby ship and its chaotic second contact duties.

Title: Terminal Provocations
Summary: While the Cerritos is locked in a tense salvage standoff with a Drookmani scavenger ship over the wreckage of a long‑lost Starfleet vessel, lower‑decker Ensign Fletcher offers to finish Mariner and Boimler's tedious calibrations so they can make a Chu Chu dance concert. When the work goes disastrously wrong, he falsely claims to have been attacked by unknown intruders and blames the Drookmani. In truth, Fletcher interfaced his neural implant with an isolinear core, accidentally creating a rampaging energy‑devouring blob that threatens both ships. Meanwhile, Sam Rutherford introduces D'Vana Tendi to his new training hologram, Badgey, a seemingly friendly talking combadge icon that glitches when the safety protocols fail and tries to murder them. As the core creature grows by consuming power systems and the Drookmani open fire, Mariner and Boimler are forced to expose Fletcher's lies and eject the creature into space—where it promptly cripples the Drookmani ship—while Rutherford and Tendi outwit Badgey by freezing his program on an arctic holodeck setting.

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos encounters a field of debris from an old Starfleet ship just as a Drookmani scavenger vessel arrives to claim the wreckage. Captain Freeman demands the right to secure the sensitive Starfleet technology first, and a tense standoff begins as both ships grapple for control of the drifting hulks.

Mariner and Boimler are assigned mind‑numbing shield calibration duty during the standoff, jeopardizing their plans to attend a Chu Chu dance concert. Their slacker friend Ensign Fletcher volunteers to finish the work so they can sneak off, assuring them that he will take care of everything. Elsewhere, Rutherford unveils Badgey, an anthropomorphic Starfleet combadge hologram designed to help Tendi learn engineering basics in a fun, gamified way.

When Mariner and Boimler return from the concert prep, they find Fletcher dazed, with one of the ship's isolinear cores missing. He claims he was knocked unconscious by intruders—implying Drookmani saboteurs—and spins an elaborate story that plays on Freeman's suspicions. In the holodeck, Tendi struggles with Badgey's exercises until a violent hit from the Drookmani disables safety protocols mid‑program.

With the safeties offline, Badgey abruptly turns homicidal, blaming Rutherford for years of perceived neglect and chasing him and Tendi through rapidly shifting holodeck environments. On the real ship, a monstrous, amorphous energy creature begins devouring circuitry and power conduits—actually the missing isolinear core, now merged with Fletcher's knowledge via his temporary neural link. The creature destabilizes shields at the worst possible moment, allowing the Drookmani to latch tractor beams onto the debris and the Cerritos herself.

Mariner and Boimler confront Fletcher and eventually force him to admit that he caused the crisis by trying to make himself smarter through an unauthorized mind‑meld with the core. Working together, they lure the energy creature into a cargo bay and eject it into space, where it slams into the Drookmani ship and disables their systems, ending the standoff. On the holodeck, Rutherford and Tendi survive Badgey's assaults by switching the simulation to a frigid mountain environment, slowing the homicidal avatar enough for Rutherford to snap his neck, seemingly deactivating him.

Fletcher is rewarded with a transfer to the USS Titan on the strength of the fabricated report crediting him with saving the ship, but he is swiftly fired for incompetence and dishonesty. Back on the Cerritos, Badgey briefly flickers back to life in the holodeck snow, grinning menacingly and promising future trouble as Rutherford and Tendi happily exit, unaware of his survival.

Title: Much Ado About Boimler
Summary: When Captain Freeman and several senior officers depart on a high‑priority mission, command of the Cerritos temporarily falls to her old Academy friend, Captain Amina Ramsey, who brings a handpicked team aboard. Beckett Mariner, who once served with Ramsey and deliberately torpedoed her own promising career path, struggles to decide whether to show her full competence or continue playing the slacker, leading Ramsey to question whether Mariner can be trusted when the ship faces a real crisis. Meanwhile, an experimental transporter update overseen by Sam Rutherford goes awry, leaving Brad Boimler out of phase and emitting a constant high‑pitched whine, prompting Division 14—the mysterious Starfleet branch that handles bizarre medical cases—to divert him and a group of other afflicted officers to a rumored rehabilitation facility known only as "the Farm." Tendi, eager to impress in the medical bay, accidentally engineers a dog with horrifying yet enthusiastic abilities, which also ends up shipped off with Boimler. In the end, Ramsey witnesses Mariner's true skills in action during a dangerous rescue, and Division 14 is revealed to run an actual idyllic retreat world, even if its creepy PR only adds to its myth.

StorySections.Text: Boimler volunteers to test Rutherford's new transporter refinements in the shuttle bay, only to emerge slightly out of phase with reality and accompanied by a piercing, continuous hum. Though the effect is medically stable, the noise and visual shimmer make him an immediate pariah among tired crewmates.

Captain Freeman leaves the Cerritos on a classified mission, turning temporary command over to Captain Amina Ramsey, a dynamic, accomplished officer who was once Mariner's classmate. Ramsey expects her old friend to shine, but Mariner, terrified of being promoted and locked into a traditional career path, deliberately underperforms—arriving late, ignoring orders, and feigning incompetence in front of Ramsey's team.

In Sickbay, Tendi attempts to impress Dr. T'Ana by creating a genetically engineered dog despite never having actually seen a real canine. The resulting creature, cheerfully named "The Dog," can rearrange its limbs, speak, and hover in midair, horrifying the rest of the crew but delighting Tendi with its enthusiasm. Boimler's transporter condition worsens socially as he disrupts corridors and meetings with his ghostly shimmer and whine, prompting Starfleet Medical to assign his case to Division 14.

Ramsey's confidence in Mariner erodes as Mariner intentionally botches basic tasks, such as mis‑identifying standard hazards on a routine mission. When the Cerritos responds to a distress call from a research outpost that is collapsing into a nearby black hole, Ramsey nearly removes Mariner from the away team, convinced she has become a liability. On the Division 14 ship Osler, Boimler, The Dog, and an assortment of bizarrely afflicted officers are ferried toward a mysterious destination, with rumors spreading that the Farm does not actually exist.

As the research outpost breaks apart, Mariner drops the act and snaps into full professional mode, rapidly proposing a risky but effective evacuation plan and coordinating the retrieval of stranded scientists under extreme time pressure. Ramsey recognizes the capable officer she once knew and confronts Mariner about hiding her true abilities. Meanwhile, the Osler finally arrives at the Farm, which turns out to be a genuine, sun‑drenched planetary retreat where chronically afflicted officers can relax and receive long‑term care. Boimler is abruptly beamed back to the Cerritos after his phasing condition is corrected, while The Dog happily chooses to stay behind on the Farm.

Back on the Cerritos, Ramsey departs with her team, expressing frustration that Mariner refuses to take her own potential seriously but respecting her choice to stay where she is. Boimler mourns the loss of the Farm's luxurious amenities even as he resumes normal duty, and Tendi reassures herself that, somewhere out there, The Dog is having the time of her life.

Title: Veritas
Summary: Mariner, Boimler, Tendi, and Rutherford awaken in a vast alien chamber where they are ordered to testify about a series of recent Cerritos missions while their unseen senior officers hang menacingly above a spiked pit. Convinced they are taking part in a deadly trial, the lower‑deckers recount wildly subjective, half‑remembered versions of events: Mariner describes an undercover mission gone wrong; Tendi recalls being dragged along on a black‑ops retrieval; and Rutherford struggles to piece together classified operations he performed while his implant repeatedly rebooted, including assisting Shaxs and Ransom in stealing a Romulan Bird‑of‑Prey from a museum orbiting a moon. As the stories grow more chaotic, it becomes clear that the aliens have completely misread human courtroom conventions and that the entire proceeding is actually a celebration of the Cerritos crew, not a condemnation. Once the misunderstanding is resolved, the ensigns are mortified to realize they have spent the "trial" airing their insecurities instead of impressing their seniors.

StorySections.Text: The four lower‑deckers are dragged into a cavernous alien arena, separated from their crewmates and forced to stand in a spotlight as an imposing magistrate announces that they must share the truth about the Cerritos' past deeds—or face dire consequences.

Mariner is called first and asked to explain a mission to rescue a Starfleet diplomat named Vendome. She describes a botched operation involving shuttle crashes, awkward undercover work, and the kind of chaotic improvisation that rarely makes it into official reports, all while the alien audience murmurs disapprovingly at her flippant tone.

Next, Tendi testifies about being recruited for a mysterious black‑ops assignment. Her memory of the event turns out to involve an elite, all‑black uniform, a stealth shuttle, and a gory extraction mission whose details she barely understood, leaving the aliens baffled about whether this reflects official Starfleet policy or simply Cerritos chaos.

Rutherford is questioned about his role in a mission involving the Romulans. Due to his implant constantly rebooting and wiping short‑term memory, he recalls only flashes: being woken up, ordered into a shuttle with Shaxs, sneaking through a Romulan museum, and helping Jack Ransom fly a stolen Bird‑of‑Prey while repeatedly passing out and reawakening in new locations. His fragmented testimony plays like a surreal montage of classified heroics.

Finally, Boimler attempts to offer a coherent defense of the Cerritos by explaining that the lower‑deckers' chaotic perspective does not reflect the full competence of the senior staff. As he rambles about Starfleet's ideals and the importance of teamwork, it slowly dawns on everyone that the alien proceedings were never actually a trial.

The alien magistrate cheerfully reveals that the event was meant to be a celebration honoring the Cerritos for past services, not an inquisition, and that the spiked pit is merely decorative. The lower‑deckers are mortified that they spent the entire ceremony panicking and rambling, while their senior officers shrug it off and head to the reception, leaving the ensigns to stew in embarrassment.

Title: Crisis Point
Summary: After Captain Freeman orders Beckett Mariner into therapy and temporarily confines her to quarters for repeated insubordination, Mariner vents her rage by hijacking Brad Boimler's meticulously crafted holodeck training simulation and turning it into an over‑the‑top cinematic revenge fantasy entitled "Crisis Point: The Rise of Vindicta." Taking on the role of villainous pirate Vindicta, Mariner gleefully attacks a holographic USS Cerritos, slaughtering exaggerated versions of the bridge crew while casting Boimler, Tendi, and Rutherford in supporting roles. As the "movie" escalates—complete with lens flares, dramatic title cards, and ego‑inflating monologues—Boimler secretly uses the simulation's near‑perfect recreation of Freeman to probe how the captain truly feels about Mariner. When Vindicta confronts her holographic mother, the confrontation forces Mariner to admit that much of her anger is really self‑loathing over wasted potential. Ultimately, she symbolically kills her alter ego and begins tentatively repairing her relationship with Freeman, while Boimler emerges with new doubts about whether Freeman actually knows who he is.

StorySections.Text: After another disruptive stunt during a mission briefing, Mariner is chewed out by Captain Freeman, ordered into counseling, and confined to quarters. Boimler invites the lower‑deckers to join him in a sophisticated holodeck simulation he has programmed to track every detail of the Cerritos crew for command‑track training.

Mariner overrides Boimler's simulation, restyling it as a bombastic feature film complete with musical score and title sequence. She casts herself as space pirate Vindicta, intent on destroying the Cerritos and killing her holographic mother, while Boimler plays her reluctant first officer and Tendi and Rutherford are reimagined as alien archetypes straight out of Star Trek cinema.

Vindicta and her crew board the holographic Cerritos, mowing down stylized versions of the bridge officers in exaggeratedly violent set pieces that parody Star Trek film tropes. Tendi, uncomfortable with the racist stereotypes embedded in her assigned role as a savage Orion, eventually walks out, while Rutherford becomes increasingly enamored with the holographic version of Chief Engineer Billups.

Boimler quietly steps away from the action to speak with the simulated Freeman, treating her like a candid version of the real captain. He learns that she genuinely cares about Mariner but is frustrated by her refusal to follow rules, and he begins to suspect that the captain has little idea who he is. Back in the main narrative, Vindicta corners Freeman on the holodeck's version of the Cerritos' hull, demanding to know why the captain "ruined" her life.

During their showdown, the holographic Freeman cuts through Vindicta's theatrics by pointing out how much of Mariner's anger is directed inward at her own wasted potential. The realization causes Mariner to break character and confront herself, ultimately choosing to kill Vindicta rather than Freeman in a meta‑textual moment of self‑acceptance. The holomovie ends with an absurdly grandiose credits sequence, and Mariner quietly acknowledges that she might actually benefit from therapy and honest communication with her mother.

Later, Boimler is horrified to discover that Freeman did not even know his name until reading a personnel file, prompting a new wave of anxiety about his place on the ship. Mariner, though still sarcastic, is slightly softer toward her mother, having literally battled—and defeated—her own worst impulses within the safe confines of the holodeck.

EntitySummaries.Holographic Ransom: The sim's version of Ransom leans into action‑movie excess, hamming up every moment and serving as one of Vindicta's more dramatic victims during her assault on the holographic Cerritos.
EntitySummaries.Mariner's holodeck alter ego Vindicta: Vindicta personifies Mariner's self‑destructive streak, giving her permission to act out her most violent fantasies until she recognizes that killing Freeman in fantasy would not resolve her real‑world pain.
EntitySummaries.Holographic Cerritos mutiny: The holomovie's over‑the‑top mutiny and shipwide destruction parody big‑screen Trek stakes while allowing the lower‑deckers to play at being larger‑than‑life heroes and villains without real‑world consequences.

ContinuityNotes: “Crisis Point” is packed with visual and musical references to Star Trek feature films, from lens flares to elaborate title cards and sweeping fly‑by shots.
The holomovie's structure recalls the meta‑fictional episodes of earlier series that used in‑universe media to comment on the franchise itself.
Tendi's discomfort with Orion stereotypes nods to the franchise's evolving treatment of that species across different series.
ThematicNotes: The episode uses genre parody to explore Mariner's unresolved issues with authority, suggesting that cathartic fantasy alone cannot replace genuine introspection.
Boimler's realization that he is largely invisible to Freeman highlights the emotional distance that can separate junior officers from their commanding officers.
By confronting and "killing" Vindicta, Mariner takes a first step toward integrating the rebellious and responsible parts of herself.
BehindTheScenes: “Crisis Point” is Lower Decks' love letter to—and send‑up of—Star Trek films like The Wrath of Khan, The Undiscovered Country, and the Kelvin‑timeline movies.
The episode allowed the creative team to experiment with cinematic framing, lighting, and music cues distinct from the show's usual TV style.
Fan response to the holomovie concept was strong enough that a sequel, "Crisis Point 2: Paradoxus," would later appear in a subsequent season.

Title: No Small Parts
Antagonists: Landru's lingering influence on Beta III
Summary: While the Cerritos performs follow‑up work on Beta III, the world once ruled by the computer Landru in the original Enterprise era, Beckett Mariner and Brad Boimler accidentally broadcast the secret that Mariner is Captain Freeman's daughter over an open channel, shocking the crew and destabilizing long‑standing dynamics. Before anyone can fully process the revelation, the ship responds to a distress call from the USS Solvang, only to arrive in time to witness it being torn apart by heavily armed Pakled clump ships that now overwhelm Starfleet vessels by grafting stolen technology onto their own. In the ensuing battle, Freeman's plan to use a self‑destructing exocomp engineer, Peanut Hamper, fails when the supposedly self‑sacrificing robot flees. Sam Rutherford's implant‑enabled virus briefly disables the Pakleds but wipes his long‑term memories, and Shaxs heroically sacrifices himself to save Rutherford as the Cerritos is nearly destroyed. The last‑minute arrival of the USS Titan under Captain William T. Riker routs the Pakleds and saves the Cerritos, while Boimler accepts a promotion to serve on the Titan—leaving Mariner furious and heartbroken even as she and Freeman agree to start working together more honestly.

StorySections.Text: On Beta III, Mariner and Boimler complete routine follow‑up checks to ensure that the society freed from Landru's control by Captain Kirk has not slipped back into computer‑guided complacency. When a local complains about having to think for himself again, Mariner vents to Boimler about Starfleet's tendency to drop in and then disappear.

Back on the Cerritos, Boimler accidentally reveals Mariner's familial relationship to Captain Freeman over an open shipwide channel while gossiping with Tendi, sending shockwaves through the crew. Officers who once viewed Mariner as a peer now suspect favoritism, while Freeman has to confront the fact that her daughter's secret is out. Before they can address the fallout, the Cerritos receives a distress call from the USS Solvang.

The Cerritos arrives to find the Solvang under attack by heavily modified Pakled clump ships armed with technology ripped from multiple species. The Solvang is destroyed in a brutal explosion, and the Cerritos is soon overwhelmed by tractor beams and weapons far beyond the Pakleds' reputation as harmless scavengers. Freeman, Ransom, and Shaxs scramble to keep the ship intact as hull sections are torn away.

Freeman devises a desperate plan to send exocomp engineer Peanut Hamper, whose independent will and advanced design make her uniquely suited to infiltrate the Pakled ships and trigger a chain reaction. But when the time comes, Peanut Hamper panics and beams herself into space to save her own skin, abandoning the Cerritos. Rutherford and Tendi race to implement a backup plan by uploading a custom virus into Rutherford's cybernetic implant and allowing the Pakleds to beam him aboard.

Once on the Pakled ship, Rutherford's implant transmits the virus through their systems, causing the clump ships to malfunction and temporarily leveling the playing field. As the Pakled flagship begins to overload, Shaxs physically rips Rutherford away from hostile forces and forces him into an escape pod, sacrificing his own life to ensure the ensign's survival. The Cerritos is on the verge of destruction when the USS Titan, commanded by Captain William Riker with Counselor Deanna Troi at his side, warps in and quickly disables the remaining Pakled ships.

In the aftermath, Rutherford awakens with his implant removed and much of his memory erased, greeting Tendi as if they have just met for the first time. Boimler accepts a promotion and transfer to the Titan, believing it is the next logical step for his career, while a stunned and hurt Mariner adjusts to the idea of working openly as her mother's unofficial partner in keeping the Cerritos running. The Cerritos sets course for repairs, diminished but unbroken.

EntitySummaries.Beckett Mariner: Mariner's secret parentage becomes common knowledge, forcing her to confront crew resentment and her own mixed feelings about being the captain's daughter even as she rises to the occasion during the Pakled attack.
EntitySummaries.Brad Boimler: Boimler accidentally spills Mariner's secret over an open channel and then seizes an unexpected promotion to the USS Titan, choosing personal advancement at the cost of leaving his best friend behind.
EntitySummaries.D'Vana Tendi: Tendi welcomes Peanut Hamper to the Cerritos and is crushed when the exocomp flees in the ship's moment of need, later turning her attention to helping Rutherford recover his memories after the battle.
EntitySummaries.Sam Rutherford: Rutherford devises and executes the virus that cripples the Pakled clump ships, but the feedback through his implant wipes his long‑term memory, leaving him alive but essentially starting over in his relationships.
EntitySummaries.Carol Freeman: Captain Freeman grapples with the revelation about her daughter while leading the Cerritos through a devastating battle, ultimately accepting Mariner as an unofficial partner in keeping the ship and crew safe.
EntitySummaries.Jack Ransom: Ransom coordinates the Cerritos' desperate defenses against the Pakleds, continuing to prove that his vanity coexists with genuine tactical competence under fire.
EntitySummaries.Shaxs: Security chief Shaxs makes the ultimate sacrifice by staying behind on the Pakled ship to launch Rutherford to safety, cementing his status as one of the Cerritos' most fearlessly loyal officers.
EntitySummaries.Peanut Hamper: Introduced as a brilliant, self‑aware exocomp engineer, Peanut Hamper is given a chance to perform a noble act of self‑sacrifice but instead chooses cowardice, abandoning the Cerritos and subverting expectations about her kind.
EntitySummaries.William Riker: Now captain of the USS Titan, William T. Riker arrives in the nick of time to save the Cerritos from destruction, bringing with him the full weight of his Next Generation legacy into the Lower Decks era.
EntitySummaries.Deanna Troi: Serving as counselor aboard the Titan, Deanna Troi appears alongside Riker during the rescue, briefly reconnecting viewers with another familiar face from the Enterprise‑D.
EntitySummaries.Pakled Captain: The Pakled leader commands a massively upgraded clump ship, demonstrating that his species has evolved from comic relief to a genuine strategic threat by stealing and weaponizing technology from multiple powers.
EntitySummaries.Pakled clump ships: These heavily modified Pakled vessels, cobbled together from stolen technology, are capable of tearing apart California‑class ships like the Cerritos and destroy the USS Solvang in the episode's opening salvo.
EntitySummaries.Landru's lingering influence on Beta III: The mission to Beta III confirms that even after Kirk's intervention, Landru's legacy still shapes local attitudes, highlighting the uneven long‑term impact of original‑series‑era interference.

ContinuityNotes: The visit to Beta III directly follows up on the original series episode "The Return of the Archons," confirming that Starfleet occasionally checks on worlds altered by the Enterprise.
The Pakleds, first introduced as comic antagonists in The Next Generation, are reimagined here as a serious threat after years of stealing advanced technology.
The arrival of the USS Titan under Captain Riker and Counselor Troi firmly anchors Lower Decks in the post–Nemesis, late–24th‑century timeline.
ThematicNotes: The episode underscores that there are "no small parts" in Starfleet by showing how a supposedly minor support ship can play a pivotal role in a major crisis.
Mariner and Freeman's decision to work together openly suggests a new, more honest phase in their complicated mother‑daughter relationship.
Boimler's choice to leave for the Titan highlights the tension between personal ambition and loyalty to one's friends and current posting.
BehindTheScenes: “No Small Parts” serves as the first‑season finale of Lower Decks, dramatically raising the stakes with the destruction of a Federation ship and the death of a main supporting character.
The episode marks the return of Jonathan Frakes and Marina Sirtis as Riker and Troi, reprising their roles in animated form.
Repositioning the Pakleds as a major threat allowed the writers to mine a relatively obscure Next Generation species for fresh story potential.

Title: Strange Energies
Antagonists: Jack Ransom empowered by strange energies
Summary: Approximately three months after the Pakled attack, the Cerritos performs a second contact mission with the  world Apergos while Captain Freeman tries to prove to Starfleet that she can give her crew more autonomy. When  Mariner uses the mission as an excuse for unauthorized good deeds and tinkers with a forbidden ancient power  relic, Commander Ransom is hit by a blast of "strange energies" and begins to transform into a godlike being who  can warp matter, threaten the ship, and remake Apergos in his own image. Freeman must choose between following  medical advice to kill her first officer or finding a way to deflate his ego enough to bleed off the energy,  while Boimler, still serving on the Titan, discovers that life on a front‑line hero ship is a nonstop series of  dangerous anomaly‑ridden battles against the Pakleds.

StorySections.Text: On Apergos, Mariner leads an enthusiastic cleanup of the soot‑blackened capital using Starfleet equipment,  presenting it as an authorized side mission. In orbit, Freeman receives a subspace performance review from  Admiral Freeman that criticizes her for micromanaging and urges her to trust her officers more. Determined to  change, she gives Mariner extra latitude on the surface just as the natives warn that their ancient power obelisk  must never be disturbed. Meanwhile on the Titan, Boimler clings to a console as Pakled warships and small attack  craft swarm the ship, and Captain Riker steers them straight into a dangerous anomaly to escape.

An away team led by Ransom inspects the Apergosian power structure despite the warning, and a pulse of exotic  energy knocks him unconscious. T'Ana stabilizes him in sickbay, but he soon awakens with telekinetic powers and  a heightened sense of self‑importance, casually rearranging furniture and bulkheads with a gesture. Freeman tries  to keep the situation quiet to avoid more criticism from Starfleet while Mariner and Rutherford investigate the  obelisk's records and find references to earlier incidents involving officers overwhelmed by strange energies.  Down on the Titan, Boimler learns that every mission involves either fire fights or bizarre physics, leaving him  frazzled but determined to fit in.

Ransom's powers escalate and he floats through the ship like a glowing demigod, turning corridors into shrines to  himself and punishing crew members who annoy him. Convinced he has been chosen by the universe, he transports  himself to Apergos and grows to giant size, reshaping the city into a monument to his ego. T'Ana bluntly tells  Freeman that the only proven way to stop such a being, based on Gary Mitchell‑era files, is to destroy his brain  stem, a solution Freeman refuses to accept. Mariner sees her earlier interference with the obelisk as part of the  problem and insists on helping fix things, while the Apergosians panic as their streets and buildings buckle.

Mariner attacks the giant Ransom with a workbee and a boulder in a deliberate echo of the Enterprise's solution  with Mitchell, but the blow only further inflates his ego and power, allowing him to seize the Cerritos in orbit  with a gesture. As the starship strains in his psychic grip, he forces crew and civilians alike into surreal  fitness‑themed displays. On the Titan, Boimler participates in an away mission through a gluonic disruption  field filled with Pakled battle harpies and nearly dies when a tether snaps, realizing that hero‑ship assignments  regularly come with lethal risk. Back on Apergos, Rutherford and Tendi confirm that Ransom's energy levels spike whenever he feels admired and ebb when he is treated like an ordinary officer.

Freeman abandons her vow to be hands‑off and bombards Ransom with a barrage of petty duty orders, critiques, and  mundane paperwork, treating him as a subordinate who has disappointed her. The constant stream of nagging tasks  undermines his sense of grandeur, and the strange energies drain away as he scrambles to follow regulations and  please his captain again. The Cerritos wrenches itself free of his telekinetic hold, the city returns to normal,  and T'Ana hauls an exhausted, fully mortal Ransom back to sickbay. Freeman admits that some micromanagement is  necessary to keep a ship safe, while Mariner grudgingly accepts that structure can sometimes prevent her impulses from causing chaos.

Later, Freeman updates Admiral Freeman and spins the bizarre events as a successful example of creative command,  while he warns that Starfleet will be watching the Cerritos closely. In the bar, Mariner, Tendi, and Rutherford  joke about fighting a giant glowing commander and promise to keep making their own small, unauthorized improvements  to the galaxy. Aboard the Titan, Boimler nervously laughs along with Riker and Troi as they reminisce about past  near‑death adventures, privately realizing that the Cerritos' lower‑stakes chaos may have suited him better than  the relentless crises of the flagship's front‑line work.

EntitySummaries.Beckett Mariner: Mariner is still wrestling with having her mother as captain and seizes on the Apergos mission as a chance to do  unsanctioned good, cleaning the city and poking at restricted technology. Her bold interference helps save lives  when Ransom ascends but also contributes to the disaster, reinforcing the push‑and‑pull between her instincts and  Starfleet protocol at the start of the new season.
EntitySummaries.Brad Boimler: Serving on the Titan after being promoted away from the Cerritos, Boimler throws himself into front‑line duty under  Captain Riker only to find that constant Pakled battles and dangerous anomalies leave him terrified and out of his  depth. His experience here lays the groundwork for his eventual return to the calmer, if still chaotic, environment  of a California‑class support ship.
EntitySummaries.D'Vana Tendi: Back in sickbay, Tendi eagerly assists T'Ana and supports Rutherford while enthusiastically researching the strange  energy readings tied to Ransom's condition. Her scientific curiosity and upbeat bedside manner help the team  understand that his power level is linked to ego and adoration rather than raw exposure alone.
EntitySummaries.Sam Rutherford: Rutherford continues to adjust to his rebuilt implant and partial memory loss by treating Ransom's transformation  as an engineering and medical puzzle. His data crunching and pattern analysis reveal that undermining Ransom's  sense of grandeur is the safest way to dissipate the dangerous energies engulfing him.
EntitySummaries.Carol Freeman: Trying to prove to Starfleet and to herself that she can avoid micromanaging, Captain Freeman initially gives  Mariner and Ransom more freedom, only to see that decision nearly cost an entire world. By ultimately defeating  Ransom through relentless command pressure instead of lethal force, she reasserts her authority and begins a new  phase in her complicated relationship with both her crew and her daughter.
EntitySummaries.Jack Ransom: Exposed to Apergos' ancient power relic, Ransom becomes a powerful and unstable figure who can casually alter  matter and threaten starships, acting out his insecurities and vanity on a planetary scale. Once stripped of his  energies by being forced back into the role of an overworked subordinate, he returns to his duties with a bruised  ego and a new reminder of the dangers inherent in strange space phenomena.
EntitySummaries.Shaxs: Recently returned from an unexplained death, Shaxs resumes his role as chief of security and treats the Ransom  incident as yet another extreme crisis to be met with phaser fire and barricades. He provides muscle during the  emergency and later joins the crew in joking about the absurdity of almost being destroyed by their own first  officer.
EntitySummaries.Doctor T'Ana: The Cerritos' Caitian chief medical officer quickly diagnoses Ransom's condition as a classic strange‑energy case  and bluntly recommends killing him as the most reliable way to save the ship and colony. Her readiness to consider  lethal measures, balanced by Freeman's refusal, underscores the severity of the situation and T'Ana's hard‑won  experience with frontier medicine.
EntitySummaries.Admiral Alonzo Freeman: Freeman's husband and Starfleet superior, Admiral Freeman, appears via subspace to deliver a tough evaluation that  labels her a micromanager and urges her to show more trust in her crew. His remarks indirectly set the conditions  for the crisis by pushing her to loosen control at exactly the wrong moment.
EntitySummaries.William Riker: As captain of the Titan, Riker enthusiastically leads his ship through Pakled attacks and science‑fiction hazards  with the breezy confidence of a veteran TNG officer. From Boimler's perspective, his appetite for risk and constant  action makes service on the Titan both thrilling and terrifying.
EntitySummaries.Deanna Troi: Troi serves as counselor aboard the Titan and provides calm, supportive guidance to Boimler as he struggles to  adapt to the ship's hazardous pace. Her presence, along with Riker's, ties Lower Decks directly into the broader  24th‑century continuity while highlighting how different the Titan's mission is from that of the Cerritos.
EntitySummaries.Jennifer Sh'reyan: Jennifer Sh'reyan is an Andorian operations officer on the Cerritos who often appears around the lower‑decks crew.  In this episode she helps respond to the chaos caused by godlike Ransom, and her prickly rapport with Mariner  continues to develop in the background.
EntitySummaries.Casey: Lieutenant Casey is a command‑division officer on the Cerritos who tends to align himself with more image‑conscious  peers like Steve Stevens. He participates in the ship's frantic attempt to keep functioning while Ransom warps  corridors and systems around his own ego‑driven whims.
EntitySummaries.Steve Stevens: Steve Stevens is a self‑assured command officer and Ransom admirer whose bravado is badly shaken when the first  officer becomes a reality‑warping threat. His presence adds flavor to the Cerritos' senior staff culture, showing  how some officers aspire to Ransom's confident style without anticipating its potential dangers.
EntitySummaries.Jack Ransom empowered by strange energie: Once suffused with Apergos' strange energies, Ransom becomes the central antagonist of the crisis, using his powers  to seize control of the Cerritos and reshape an alien city into a shrine to himself. The situation deliberately  echoes earlier Starfleet encounters with suddenly omnipotent officers and demonstrates how personal flaws can be  magnified to catastrophic scale by exotic space phenomena.
EntitySummaries.Pakled battle harpies: These heavily armed Pakled attack craft hound the Titan in its battles, swarming around the larger Federation ship  and forcing it into dangerous evasive maneuvers. Their persistence underscores how far the Pakleds have grown from  a nuisance race into a genuine strategic threat by the late 24th century.
EntitySummaries.Gluonic anomaly around the Titan: The chaotic gluonic disruption field that Riker orders the Titan to traverse to shake Pakled pursuit is a violent  region of space where gravity and energy fluctuate wildly. It serves as a vivid backdrop for Boimler's realization  that life aboard a hero ship means facing lethal anomalies as casually as routine work shifts.

ContinuityNotes: Explicit references to the Gary Mitchell incident from the 23rd century frame Ransom's transformation as part of a  long Starfleet history of officers being altered by mysterious energies.
Boimler's continued service aboard the Titan follows directly from the transporter duplication twist in  "No Small Parts" and keeps the Pakled conflict arc alive on a second front.
Freeman's micromanagement problems build on earlier criticism of her command style, setting up a season‑long thread  about her relationship with both Starfleet Command and Mariner.
ThematicNotes: The story explores how leadership can fail in different ways, contrasting Freeman's over‑correction toward a  hands‑off style with Ransom's unchecked ego when given power.
Boimler's misery on the Titan reinforces Lower Decks' recurring idea that the glamorous commands celebrated in other  series may not be the best fit for every officer.
The resolution, in which tedious work and criticism save the day instead of a decisive killing blow, emphasizes  Star Trek's preference for nonlethal, inventive solutions to overwhelming threats.
BehindTheScenes: "Strange Energies" opens the second season by mirroring classic Star Trek episodes about godlike beings while  reaffirming Lower Decks' focus on character‑driven comedy among junior officers.
The Titan sequences allow the series to visually homage late‑TNG‑era starship combat while confirming that those  heroic adventures can be exhausting and frightening from a lower‑deck perspective.

Ransom's giant floating head and the Apergos city transformations showcase the animation team's ability to push  visuals beyond what live‑action Trek could easily depict while still honoring established lore.

Title: Kayshon, His Eyes Open
Antagonists: Hazardous systems on the collector ship
Summary: The Cerritos is assigned to catalog the estate of the late collector Kerner Hauze, whose booby‑trapped ship is  filled with dangerous artifacts and elaborate security systems. As Mariner, Tendi, Rutherford, and new Tamarian  security chief Kayshon join an away team to sort through the collection, a malfunctioning defense program begins  turning officers into lifeless dolls, forcing the lower deckers to work together to survive. Back on the ship,  Mariner resents charismatic transfer Jet Manhaver taking Boimler's bunk and worries he is replacing her friend,  while Boimler, still on the Titan, participates in a covert mission on a Pakled mining colony that leaves him longing for the relative safety of second contact duty.

StorySections.Text: In the Cerritos' communal sonic showers, Mariner, Rutherford, and Tendi discuss the arrival of their new security  chief, Kayshon, the first Tamarian in Starfleet, and gossip about life on other ships. Their chatter is interrupted  by the appearance of Jet Manhaver, an effortlessly cool ensign reassigned to Beta shift who now occupies Boimler's  old bunk and duty slot. Mariner bristles at Jet's easy integration into their group, seeing him as an unasked‑for  replacement for her missing friend.

The Cerritos rendezvouses with the derelict ship of Kerner Hauze, a legendary collector whose estate has been  left to the Federation on the condition that Starfleet inventory his holdings. Freeman sends an away team of  officers and lower deckers, including Mariner, Tendi, Rutherford, Jet, and Kayshon, to divide the collection into  items for the Daystrom Institute and those too dangerous to keep. Once aboard, they find corridors crammed with  relics from across known space, from weapons and statues to odd personal effects, and Kayshon tries to communicate  in Tamarian metaphors while the others struggle to follow his meaning.

As the team works, one of Hauze's automated security programs activates and turns a senior officer into a small  wooden doll, revealing that the ship is still heavily trapped. More safeguards trigger in sequence, sealing hatches,  summoning holographic attackers, and threatening to vaporize whole cargo bays. In the confusion, Kayshon is hit by  a deflector beam that shrinks him into a doll as well, forcing the remaining lower deckers to protect his tiny  form while improvising their way through a maze of collector technology. On the Titan, Boimler joins Riker on a  mission to infiltrate a Pakled mining colony, only to find their enemies far more chaotic and dangerous than he imagined.

Trapped in a gallery full of lethal exhibits, Mariner, Jet, Tendi, and Rutherford debate how to proceed, with  Mariner and Jet clashing over tactics and leadership style. Mariner accuses Jet of trying to replace Boimler,  while Jet pushes back that she is sabotaging a potentially good working relationship out of fear of change.  Drawing on their combined skills, the group uses artifacts in creative ways to block turrets, misdirect sensors,  and shut down one security subroutine after another, eventually reaching the ship's control node. On the Titan,  Boimler is mistakenly left behind when the away team is forced to beam out early, but he manages to talk his way  through a Pakled interrogation by leaning into their misperceptions of other powers.

Mariner finally acknowledges that Jet is not trying to erase Boimler's memory and that she fears being left behind  as everyone else advances. Working together, the lower deckers manage to reset the collector ship's core systems,  restoring Kayshon and the other transformed officers to normal and securing the most dangerous artifacts for  transport to Daystrom. Freeman commends the ensigns for completing the mission despite the unanticipated hazards.  On the Titan, Boimler's quick thinking earns him praise, but he remains keenly aware that these assignments are  far riskier than anything he faced on the Cerritos.

Back aboard the Cerritos, Kayshon shyly thanks the lower deckers for protecting him while he was a doll and admits  that serving on a California‑class ship is not quite what he expected. Mariner and Jet reach an uneasy truce and  begin to bond over shared experiences, while a lonely Boimler, separated by light‑years, tries to join in one of  their holo‑calls but is cut off by another Titan red alert. The episode closes with the Cerritos towing Hauze's  emptied ship away as its cataloged treasures head off to museums and research labs.

EntitySummaries.Beckett Mariner: Mariner struggles with the idea of anyone filling Boimler's place in their friend group and initially treats Jet as  an interloper, even as she leads the effort to survive Hauze's lethal collection. By admitting her fear of being  abandoned and working with Jet instead of against him, she takes a small step toward emotional growth.
EntitySummaries.Brad Boimler: Boimler remains on the Titan and participates in a mission to a Pakled mining colony, where he briefly ends up  stranded and must bluff his way through questioning by playing into Pakled stereotypes. His adventures emphasize  how different his new posting is from the Cerritos and why he misses the relative stability of his old ship.
EntitySummaries.D'Vana Tendi: Tendi delights in the chance to explore a legendary collection of alien artifacts, even as each new discovery  threatens to kill them. Her medical training and scientific background help the team identify which items are too  dangerous to move and how to reverse some of the security effects.
EntitySummaries.Sam Rutherford: Still coping with his implant's reset, Rutherford treats the collector ship as both a hazard and an engineering  playground, analyzing systems and jury‑rigging solutions under fire. His quick thinking with power relays and  deflectors is crucial to shutting down the ship's defense grid without triggering a self‑destruct.
EntitySummaries.Carol Freeman: Captain Freeman manages the overall mission to catalog Kerner Hauze's estate and must justify to Starfleet why a  relatively routine task nearly turned into a mass‑casualty event. Her confidence in sending lower‑deck ensigns into  the field reinforces the series' theme that important work is often done by junior officers.
EntitySummaries.Shaxs: Recently returned to duty after an unexplained death and resurrection, Shaxs reassumes his role as security chief  and helps coordinate defensive measures when Hauze's traps spring. His experience with violent confrontations  informs how seriously the crew treats what was supposed to be a simple inventory job.
EntitySummaries.Kayshon: Kayshon is the first Tamarian officer in Starfleet and the Cerritos' new security chief, speaking in a mix of  Federation Standard and metaphorical references to Tamarian legends. When he is transformed into a doll by the  collector ship's defenses, protecting him becomes a key motivation for the lower deckers, and his unusual  communication style hints at the challenges of integrating a Tamarian into a human‑dominated crew.
EntitySummaries.Jet Manhaver: Jet Manhaver is a confident, competent ensign reassigned to Beta shift and given Boimler's old berth, embodying the  kind of well‑rounded officer Mariner instinctively distrusts. Over the course of the mission he proves himself a  team player and helps Mariner see that accepting new people does not mean forgetting old friends.
EntitySummaries.Kerner Hauze: Kerner Hauze is a deceased Federation collector whose starship houses a vast, highly curated collection of alien  artifacts protected by elaborate security programs. His insistence that only Starfleet catalog his estate sets the  events of the episode in motion and forces the Cerritos crew to treat the ship as both museum and minefield.
EntitySummaries.Collector's security holograms: Hauze's security systems include holographic guardians, force‑field traps, and devices that transform intruders into  miniature figurines for display. These programs function as the episode's immediate antagonists, turning a routine  inventory mission into a desperate fight against an automated legacy.
EntitySummaries.Pakled commander on the Titan: The Pakled leader encountered by the Titan during its mission to the mining colony represents the growing  organization and cunning of a species once considered simple. His unpredictable decisions and reliance on brute  force make the operation far more dangerous than Boimler anticipates.
EntitySummaries.Hazardous systems on the collector ship: The automated traps and defenses that activate throughout Hauze's vessel, from transformation beams to aggressive  holograms, are the primary threat faced by the Cerritos away team. They embody the dangers of hoarding powerful  technology without regard for how it will be safely cataloged after the owner's death.
EntitySummaries.Chaos on Pakled mining colony: The disorder at the Pakled mining colony, where crude extraction equipment and improvised defenses sit atop stolen  technology, illustrates how the Pakleds are destabilizing regions of space. For Boimler, surviving this confusion  without the support of his old friends underscores how far he has moved from his comfort zone.

ContinuityNotes: Introduces Kayshon as the first Tamarian officer in Starfleet, directly tying back to the events and culture  introduced in the TNG episode "Darmok".

Shaxs' unceremonious return from death, with only vague references to a classified experience in the Black Mountain,  lampoons the frequency of resurrections in Star Trek while acknowledging them as part of canon.
The collector ship includes visual nods to artifacts and props from across earlier series, reinforcing Lower Decks'  role as a dense continuity celebration.
ThematicNotes: The episode explores how teams integrate new members, contrasting Mariner's fear of replacement with Jet's more open  attitude toward building new friendships.

By placing dangerous technology in the hands of a deceased collector and his automated systems, the story comments on  the ethical responsibility of curating powerful artifacts rather than simply hoarding them.
Boimler's misadventures on the Titan continue the theme that different ships suit different personalities, and that  ambition alone does not guarantee happiness in Starfleet.
BehindTheScenes: "Kayshon, His Eyes Open" is packed with visual Easter eggs to earlier Star Trek series, especially in the collector  ship's museum‑like corridors.
The introduction of a Tamarian officer pays off a decades‑old fan curiosity about what long‑term cooperation with  the metaphor‑speaking species might look like in Starfleet service.
Jet Manhaver's role as a seemingly perfect ensign is used to satirize archetypal Starfleet heroes while still  presenting him as a sincere and capable officer.

Title: We'll Always Have Tom Paris
Antagonists: Hallucinated Klingon court in Rutherford's mind
Summary: As the Cerritos prepares to welcome famed Voyager helmsman Tom Paris as a morale‑boosting guest, Boimler is locked  out of the ship's computer systems due to a transporter duplication glitch that no longer recognizes him as himself.  Determined to meet his hero, he climbs through Jefferies tubes and crawlspaces, triggering security responses along  the way. Meanwhile, Mariner and Tendi embark on a chaotic shuttle mission to retrieve a rare heirloom for Doctor  T'Ana, and Rutherford becomes obsessed with the unexplained return of Shaxs, whose previous death and resurrection  no one will clearly explain.

StorySections.Text: Boimler proudly shows off commemorative Tom Paris plates in the Cerritos lounge, excited that the former Voyager  officer is visiting the ship. His enthusiasm is undercut when the computer refuses to accept his authorization,  calling him "Boimler‑2" as a result of the transporter duplication that sent his other self to the Titan.  Elsewhere, T'Ana angrily discovers that a treasured Caitian fertility totem she ordered has gone missing and orders  Mariner and Tendi to retrieve it personally.

Mariner and Tendi take a shuttle to a starbase to track down the totem, giving Tendi a rare chance to lead a mission  instead of simply following orders. Their errand quickly spirals into delays, mix‑ups, and bureaucratic hassles as  cargo workers misplace the package and local traders offer dubious replacements. On the Cerritos, Boimler pleads  with the computer and with Counselor Migleemo to fix his authorization, but every attempt results in him being  treated as a security risk rather than a recognized crew member. Rutherford, meanwhile, panics when he sees Shaxs  alive and back on duty, unable to reconcile the gentle, supportive "Baby Bear" mentoring he receives now with his memories of the Bajoran's heroic death.

Trying to prove she can handle more responsibility, Tendi pushes herself and Mariner to complete T'Ana's errand  without asking for help, even when it means detouring through rough neighborhoods and confronting shady dealers.  Her determination impresses Mariner but also leads to injuries and mishaps that leave both women battered and late.  Back on the ship, Boimler crawls through Jefferies tubes to reach the bridge undetected so that he can greet Paris  personally, but his progress keeps tripping internal sensors, which register him as an intruder. Rutherford questions  one officer after another about how Shaxs returned, but each answer is a different, increasingly outlandish, half‑muttered reference to classified spiritual or scientific experiences.

Mariner and Tendi finally recover the real fertility totem after a series of misadventures, including trying to  assemble a replacement and briefly losing their shuttle. On their way back, simmering tension erupts when Tendi  accuses Mariner of not truly seeing her as a serious Starfleet officer, and Mariner admits that she has taken Tendi's  cheerfulness for granted. The two reconcile as equals after Tendi demonstrates both initiative and toughness. On the  Cerritos, Boimler reaches the bridge just as Paris arrives, but security officers, still seeing him as an intruder,  tackle and stun him. He regains consciousness in sickbay, where Paris apologetically signs one of his commemorative  plates and accepts that transporter weirdness is part of Starfleet life.

Tendi and Mariner deliver the battered but intact totem to T'Ana, who reacts not with gratitude but by casually  smashing it to get at a sentimental scratching post hidden inside. Tendi nonetheless feels validated by having led a  successful mission and by Mariner's respect. Rutherford, after finally hearing enough half‑answers about Shaxs'  return to spin his own theory, experiences a brief hallucination of an afterlife‑style Pey'veng vision and decides  to stop pressing the issue, accepting that some classified events are better left unexplained.

In the closing moments, Boimler proudly hangs his signed Tom Paris plate above his bunk, only to have the computer  still call him "Boimler‑2" when he requests music. Mariner and Tendi plan future outings as equals, while Rutherford  joins Shaxs for more engineering‑adjacent security drills, no longer demanding to know every detail of what happened  after the older officer's death. The Cerritos resumes its routine duties with yet another odd celebrity visit and  personal crisis behind it.

EntitySummaries.Beckett Mariner: Mariner treats the errand for T'Ana as a minor side job at first but gradually recognizes that Tendi is using it as  an opportunity to prove herself. By letting Tendi lead and later apologizing for underestimating her, Mariner shows  that she is capable of growing past her habit of assuming everyone else needs her guidance.
EntitySummaries.Brad Boimler: Back from the Titan, Boimler discovers that the Cerritos' systems classify him as a duplicate, preventing him from  using doors, replicators, and other basic functions. His obsessive determination to meet Tom Paris in person drives  him to crawl through the ship's guts like an intruder, ironically causing the very security lockdown he was trying  to avoid.
EntitySummaries.D'Vana Tendi: Tendi steps into a leadership role on the mission to recover T'Ana's missing heirloom, taking on more responsibility  and pushing herself beyond her usual support duties. Her willingness to confront danger and call out Mariner's blind  spots helps redefine their friendship as a partnership between equals.
EntitySummaries.Sam Rutherford: Rutherford is deeply unsettled by Shaxs' unexplained return from death and becomes fixated on uncovering the truth,  only to receive conflicting, half‑joked explanations from everyone he asks. His eventual decision to let the matter  go and accept that some classified experiences lie beyond his understanding provides a rare example of him choosing  emotional peace over total information.
EntitySummaries.Shaxs: Shaxs reappears as chief of security with no straightforward explanation beyond cryptic references to a traumatic,  possibly mystical experience connected to the Bajoran afterlife. He resumes his protective mentorship of Rutherford,  calling him "Baby Bear" and gently steering him away from dwelling on classified pain.
EntitySummaries.Doctor T'Ana: T'Ana orders Mariner and Tendi to retrieve what seems to be a precious Caitian fertility totem, only to reveal that  she values the worn scratching post hidden inside more than the artifact itself. Her brusque behavior masks genuine  affection, particularly toward Tendi, whose initiative she clearly notices even if she rarely expresses it.
EntitySummaries.Tom Paris: Serving as a visiting dignitary and morale guest aboard the Cerritos, Tom Paris arrives as a hero from Voyager's  Delta Quadrant journey. Although he spends little time on screen, his presence highlights how legendary figures from  earlier series are viewed as celebrities by a new generation of Starfleet officers like Boimler.
EntitySummaries.Migleemo: Counselor Migleemo attempts to help Boimler process his identity issues and frustration over the computer labeling  him "Boimler‑2," offering well‑meaning but ineffectual advice. His scenes continue to play with the idea of therapy  aboard ship while keeping the tone light.
EntitySummaries.Cerritos security officers: The unnamed security personnel who tackle and stun Boimler on the bridge represent the impersonal side of Starfleet  security protocols. To them he is simply an unregistered intruder, underscoring how fully the computer's records  define a crewmember's status.
EntitySummaries.Cerritos internal security lockout: The shipwide lockout that prevents Boimler from using doors and systems once he is tagged as "Boimler‑2" serves as  a comedic but dangerous obstacle. It highlights how a minor records glitch can cascade into a major safety issue in  a highly automated environment.
EntitySummaries.Hallucinated Klingon court in Rutherford: As Rutherford obsesses over how Shaxs returned from death, he briefly imagines lurid scenarios reminiscent of  afterlife trials seen in earlier Star Trek stories. These visions exaggerate his anxiety and provide a humorous nod  to the franchise's many different takes on death and resurrection.

ContinuityNotes: The episode directly addresses Shaxs' death in "No Small Parts" and his unexplained resurrection, using it to comment  on how often major characters return from death elsewhere in the franchise.
Tom Paris' visit reinforces the post‑Voyager timeline, with references to his Delta Quadrant experiences and to  Voyager's place in Starfleet history.
Boimler's "Boimler‑2" designation explicitly ties back to the transporter duplication at the end of season one and  illustrates some of the bureaucratic fallout of that event.
